meta.name: Curriculum-Making Alignment Framework (Conceptual x Actor)
notes: Designed for an interactive web explainer + teacher-facing diagnostic tools.
All categories are ideal-types; real settings often hybridize under constraints.
v0.4 adds: richer design type summaries; concise practice examples for philosophies and conceptions; and a Priestley-informed actor-system layer including a Supra level.
Important: actor sites do not have fixed ideologies; any actor may draw on different conceptual lenses, and curriculum emerges through negotiation across sites.

scale.label: Naive Realism
scale.definition: Reality can be understood through appropriate methods.

scale.label: Structural Realism
scale.definition: Theories describe aspects/structures of reality; underlying essence may remain uncertain.

scale.label: Critical Realism
scale.definition: Reality exists and can be approached through critical examination of deeper mechanisms.

scale.label: Bounded Relativism
scale.definition: Psychological constructions of reality are valid within cultural/moral/cognitive boundaries.

scale.label: Relativism
scale.definition: Reality is multiple and constructed; no mind-independent reality is accessible/meaningful.

scale.label: Objectivism
scale.definition: Meaning is in the object, independent of the knower.

scale.label: Constructionism
scale.definition: Meaning emerges from subject–object interaction; the knower constructs meaning.

scale.label: Subjectivism
scale.definition: Meaning is in the subject; the knower assigns meaning.

levels.name: Educational Philosophy
levels.guiding_question: Why educate? What kind of person/society is education for? (aims/ends)

levels.name: Curriculum Conception (Curriculum Orientation)
levels.guiding_question: What is curriculum, primarily for, in institutional schooling?

levels.name: Curriculum Design Type (Organizational Form)
levels.guiding_question: How is content/experience organized across time and subjects? (scope/sequence/integration)

mechanism_summary: Philosophy supplies value/legitimacy for aims and a worldview about knowledge and persons.
Curriculum conception translates those assumptions into a dominant 'function of curriculum' language for institutions.
Design type operationalizes that function into structures (scope/sequence/integration) and default evidence systems.
In practice, feedback loops occur: implementation evidence and constraints can reshape conceptions and even aims.
relationship_notes: The conceptual chain is best understood as a set of mutually-influencing lenses: educational philosophy, curriculum conception, and curriculum design type often cohere, but they can also be in tension.

Influence is not strictly one-way. For example, a chosen design type (e.g., problem-centered) can gradually reshape a school's curriculum conception and even its philosophical commitments through practice, evidence, and institutional routines.
In operational curriculum, hybridization is common: teachers and systems often weave multiple lenses together under practical constraints.

axis_B_curriculum_making.premise: Curriculum is dynamically made through interaction among actors across system levels; agency is ecological (enabled/constrained by structural, cultural, and material conditions).

sites_of_activity.description: Transnational/global discourse, benchmarks, and policy borrowing; professional networks; research and thought-leadership.
National/state/provincial curriculum policy, standards, qualifications, accountability regimes.
District/local authority and school-level translation: leadership, timetables, resourcing, professional learning, local priorities.
Classroom enactment: teachers and students interpret, adapt, and negotiate curriculum-in-use.
Moment-to-moment interaction and learner experience: participation, identity, meaning-making, assessment talk.

supra.label: Supra (Transnational)
supra.description: Transnational influences, policy borrowing/lending, global discourses and benchmarks.

macro.label: Macro (System)
macro.description: National/regional policy, standards, assessment regimes, system-wide strategies.

meso.label: Meso (Institution/Network)
meso.description: Schools, districts, organizations and networks translating policy into support, resources and routines.

micro.label: Micro (Classroom/Teacher)
micro.description: Teachers’ planning and teaching practices where curriculum is interpreted and enacted.

nano.label: Nano (Learner/Interaction)
nano.description: Learners’ moment-to-moment experience and participation shaping the lived curriculum.

key_principles: Curriculum making is a social practice enacted across multiple sites; it is not linear 'implementation'.
Influence is often bidirectional: top-down mandates interact with bottom-up interpretations and negotiations.
Different actors may hold different conceptual lenses (philosophy/conception/design) and these differences can surface as tensions in operational curriculum.

educational_philosophies.label: Perennialism
aims: initiate learners into enduring ideas and classic disciplines
educational_philosophies.definition: An educational philosophy that treats enduring ideas and disciplined reasoning as the core purpose of schooling, often via classic texts and established disciplines.

practice_examples.one_liner: Students revisit a canonical text to practice disciplined reasoning about enduring questions.
practice_examples.planning: Unit anchored in one classic text + a small set of 'enduring questions' (e.g., justice, virtue).
practice_examples.instruction: Socratic seminar; teacher presses for definitions, logic, textual evidence.
practice_examples.assessment: Timed analytic essay + oral defense focusing on argument quality and textual warrants.
practice_examples.tradeoff: May under-serve local relevance or diverse knowledges unless deliberately broadened.

practice_examples.instruction: Teacher models proofs; students critique peers' reasoning.
practice_examples.assessment: Assessment emphasizes proof structure, clarity, and logical validity over speed.

curriculum_design_types.definition: A curriculum design that organizes learning primarily around disciplines/subjects and their internal structures (concepts, skills, and canonical knowledge). Design a short weekly cumulative quiz blueprint (skills + concepts)
instruction_practices: Daily retrieval warm-up (2–4 items) on prior skills
I-do / We-do / You-do with worked examples and think-aloud
Guided practice with immediate error correction and anchor methods
Independent practice + structured homework review
assessment_practices: Weekly cumulative quiz (10–15 items) mixing procedural + application items
Item analysis to spot class misconceptions and re-teach targets
Mastery checks (exit ticket) before moving to next sub-skill
evidence_of_learning: Correct method selection in unfamiliar word problems

tradeoffs.risk: Overemphasis on speed/coverage can reduce conceptual sense-making.
tradeoffs.mitigation: Add brief 'why this works' prompts and 1–2 conceptual representations each lesson.

tradeoffs.risk: Learners who miss prerequisites may fall behind.
tradeoffs.mitigation: Use short re-teach loops and targeted practice groups.

adaptations: If time is tight: keep the retrieval warm-up + exit ticket, reduce homework volume but keep spaced practice.

practice_examples.title: History survey with sourcing routines
practice_examples.one_liner: Discipline routines make 'doing history' explicit while maintaining coverage.
practice_examples.planning: Select 3–5 core questions per unit (chronological or thematic) to structure the survey; Curate a primary-source packet (short, contrasting documents) for each question; Plan explicit instruction of disciplinary heuristics (sourcing/contextualization/corroboration); Draft a DBQ-style writing prompt aligned to unit content
practice_examples.instruction: Mini-lecture to establish key events/concepts (10–15 mins) + guided note-making; Document analysis routine (source → claim → evidence → bias/limits); Whole-class discussion anchored in texts; teacher prompts for evidence use; Modeled paragraph writing (claim-evidence-reasoning) before independent essay work
practice_examples.assessment: Short content quizzes (retrieval of key concepts/vocabulary); DBQ essay scored with a CER rubric (claim, evidence quality, reasoning); Annotated document set (students highlight evidence and write margin notes)

DBQ essay scored with a CER rubric (claim, evidence quality, reasoning)
Annotated document set (students highlight evidence and write margin notes)
evidence_of_learning: Accurate use of historical concepts and timeline

tradeoffs.risk: Survey pacing can create shallow understanding.
tradeoffs.mitigation: Use fewer core questions and deeper document sets; spiral key concepts.

adaptations: If resources are limited: use short document excerpts + structured graphic organizers for analysis.

practice_examples.title: Broad-fields science with concept progression
practice_examples.one_liner: Related disciplines are integrated into a broad field while preserving conceptual progression.
practice_examples.planning: Sequence concepts (e.g., energy → ecosystems) using a concept progression map; Align each lab to a target concept and a target science practice (measure, model, explain); Prepare lab directions + safety steps; pre-lab questions for readiness; Plan 'checkpoints' for common misconceptions
practice_examples.instruction: Explicit concept instruction with models/representations (diagram, simulation, analogy); Guided lab with defined roles and data tables; Whole-class sense-making discussion: patterns in data → explanation; Concept map or summary write-up to consolidate
practice_examples.assessment: Lab report scored with rubric (data quality, interpretation, explanation); Unit test mixing selected-response and constructed-response explanation items; Practical skill check (e.g., measurement, graphing) during lab

tradeoffs.mitigation: Add a prediction + explanation prompt and a post-lab claim-evidence task.

adaptations: If lab time is limited: run a teacher demo + student data analysis and explanation task.

curriculum_design_types.note_on_hybridization: In real settings, design choices are often hybrid; this design type describes the dominant organizing principle.

aims: Develop disciplinary knowledge and ways of thinking (e.g., historical reasoning, scientific explanation).
Build foundational skills and academic literacies through structured progression.
organizing_principle: Subject/discipline boundaries (or broad-fields that still retain disciplinary logics).
Planned scope-and-sequence; coverage and progression are explicit.
planning_bias: Pacing guides, unit maps, and content progression charts.
Textbook/program alignment; selection of 'core' content and exemplars.
Prerequisite analysis (what must come before what).
pedagogy_bias: Explicit teaching, modeling, guided practice; structured discussion anchored in content.
Frequent checks for understanding; practice for fluency and accuracy.
assessment_bias: Criterion-referenced tests/quizzes aligned to objectives; essays or lab reports judged against discipline-based criteria.
Emphasis on accuracy, completeness, and disciplinary conventions.
evidence_standard: Demonstrable mastery of core knowledge/skills (recall, application, disciplined reasoning).
Consistency across learners (comparability) is often valued.
common_hybrids: Subject-centered + inquiry routines (bounded inquiry within a discipline).
Subject-centered + performance tasks (apply content to authentic tasks).

curriculum_design_types.label: Learner-Centered Design
curriculum_design_types.definition: A curriculum design that organizes learning around learners’ interests, needs, experiences, and developmental trajectories. It values agency, choice, and meaning-making, and treats curriculum as something that can be co-constructed and adapted in response to learners.

subtypes.label: Child-Centered Design
planning_practices: start from learners' questions; co-plan inquiries; flexible pacing
diagnose readiness and interests; differentiate pathways
instruction_practices: workshops, centers, exploration; teacher as facilitator
student choice in tasks and products; formative conferencing
assessment_practices: observational records; formative check-ins; student self-assessment
portfolio of artifacts demonstrating growth

practice_examples.title: Play-Based Inquiry with Choice Centers
practice_examples.planning: Set developmental aims (language, numeracy, social); design 4–5 centers with open-ended materials; plan observation focus each week
practice_examples.instruction: Children choose centers; teacher observes, questions, and extends play; brief group share to surface ideas; mini-lessons only when needed
practice_examples.assessment: Anecdotal records + photos; learning stories; short teacher notes linked to developmental indicators; family conference portfolio
planning_practices: Set developmental aims (language, numeracy, social); design 4–5 centers with open-ended materials; plan observation focus each week

assessment_practices: Anecdotal records + photos; learning stories; short teacher notes linked to developmental indicators; family conference portfolio

subtypes.label: Experience-Centered (Activity) Design
planning_practices: design rich experiences (fieldwork, making, simulations) that generate questions
plan reflection cycles to turn experience into learning
instruction_practices: experiential tasks; debrief protocols; iterative making
community resources and authentic audiences
assessment_practices: performance + reflection; peer feedback; narrative assessment
rubrics for process (planning, iteration, reflection)

practice_examples.title: Experience-Centered Unit (Community Walk → Writing & Mapping)
practice_examples.planning: Plan a local observation walk; choose a few experience prompts (sounds, signs, people); prepare mapping and journaling templates
practice_examples.instruction: Students observe and record; class debrief to generate shared questions; write narratives/information texts drawn from experience
practice_examples.assessment: Assessment via writing portfolio + self-reflection; teacher conference notes on descriptive language and organization
planning_practices: Plan a local observation walk; choose a few experience prompts (sounds, signs, people); prepare mapping and journaling templates
instruction_practices: Students observe and record; class debrief to generate shared questions; write narratives/information texts drawn from experience
assessment_practices: Assessment via writing portfolio + self-reflection; teacher conference notes on descriptive language and organization

subtypes.label: Humanistic Design
planning_practices: plan for belonging, identity, and emotional safety as explicit design goals
integrate value clarification and self-reflection opportunities
instruction_practices: dialogic circles; journaling; choice-based reading/writing
teacher stance: empathy, authenticity, respect; co-created norms
assessment_practices: student-led conferences; reflective portfolios
qualitative indicators (agency, self-regulation, meaning-making)
tradeoffs: risk of being seen as 'soft' if outcomes unclear

practice_examples.title: Humanistic Advisory (Belonging & Identity Portfolio)
practice_examples.planning: Co-create community norms; plan weekly identity prompts; prepare optional modalities (writing, art, audio)
practice_examples.instruction: Circle discussions; reflective journaling; peer listening protocols; teacher coaching conversations
practice_examples.assessment: Narrative feedback (no numeric grades); self-assessment rubric for reflection depth; optional sharing with family
planning_practices: Co-create community norms; plan weekly identity prompts; prepare optional modalities (writing, art, audio)
instruction_practices: Circle discussions; reflective journaling; peer listening protocols; teacher coaching conversations
assessment_practices: Narrative feedback (no numeric grades); self-assessment rubric for reflection depth; optional sharing with family

subtypes.label: Radical / Reform Design
planning_practices: co-determine aims with learners; critical examination of schooling itself
plan for voice, dissent, and negotiated curriculum
instruction_practices: problem-posing dialogue; student-led investigations; self-directed learning contracts
peer teaching and democratic governance routines
assessment_practices: negotiated criteria; public exhibitions; reflective critique
evidence includes participation in collective decisions and action
tradeoffs: difficult to align to mandated standards

example_cards.context: Youth inquiry on school discipline policy

practice_examples.title: Student-Designed Independent Study Contract
practice_examples.planning: Student proposes a question/project; negotiate a learning contract (aims, milestones, evidence); plan weekly check-ins
practice_examples.instruction: Student-led inquiry; teacher as mentor; peer critique sessions; public sharing milestone
practice_examples.assessment: Contract evidence set (artifact + rationale + reflection); rubric focuses on inquiry rigor, iteration, and learning narrative
planning_practices: Student proposes a question/project; negotiate a learning contract (aims, milestones, evidence); plan weekly check-ins
instruction_practices: Student-led inquiry; teacher as mentor; peer critique sessions; public sharing milestone
assessment_practices: Contract evidence set (artifact + rationale + reflection); rubric focuses on inquiry rigor, iteration, and learning narrative

curriculum_design_types.primary_function: Promote engagement, autonomy, and holistic development by building curriculum from learners’ experiences.
planning_practices: Elicit learner interests/needs; co-construct driving questions or themes.
Design flexible pathways, choice menus, and differentiated supports.
Plan for classroom climate, routines for reflection, and formative checkpoints.
instruction_practices: Workshop/center-based learning; conferencing; responsive mini-lessons.
Experiential learning cycles (do–reflect–revise); collaborative inquiry.
Emphasis on student voice, agency, and community norms.
assessment_practices: Portfolios, learning narratives, self- and peer-assessment.
Rubrics emphasize growth, reflection, and quality of work relative to goals.
Conferences and exhibitions as key evidence moments.
curriculum_design_types.evidence_standard: Developmental evidence of growth, understanding, and agency (often qualitative and portfolio-based).

practice_examples.title: Writer’s workshop with student choice
practice_examples.one_liner: Students choose topics and genres; teacher supports craft through mini-lessons and conferences.
practice_examples.planning: Set a broad writing goal (e.g., 'write to communicate and revise for clarity') and offer a genre choice menu; Collect 2–3 mentor texts for each genre and plan short mini-lessons (craft moves); Schedule regular teacher-student conferences (rotation plan) and peer feedback protocols; Co-create a 'success criteria' checklist with students (what good looks like)
practice_examples.instruction: Mini-lesson (5–10 mins) + model a craft move; Independent writing time with teacher conferencing (coaching questions, next-step goals); Peer feedback using a simple protocol (warm/cool feedback tied to criteria); Daily reflection (What did I try? What will I revise next?)
practice_examples.assessment: Portfolio of drafts + final pieces showing revision history; Conference notes as formative evidence; student self-assessment against criteria; Rubric focuses on communication, craft, and growth (not just correctness)

practice_examples.title: Interest-based inquiry centers
practice_examples.one_liner: Rotating centers let students explore interests while building core capabilities.
practice_examples.planning: Define a broad inquiry theme (e.g., 'How do systems change?') and design 4–6 learning stations; Prepare materials for exploration (texts, manipulatives, media) with multiple entry points; Create a choice board that balances freedom with required experiences; Plan short check-in moments (midpoint share, exit reflection) to surface learning
practice_examples.instruction: Learners choose stations, record questions/observations in a learning journal; Teacher circulates to probe thinking and suggest next challenges; Small-group share-outs to compare findings and refine questions; Mini-lesson inserted when a common need emerges (just-in-time teaching)
practice_examples.assessment: Learning journal snapshots (questions, sketches, explanations) reviewed weekly; Student conference: learner explains what they discovered and what they want to pursue next; Culminating artifact (poster/model/story) assessed with a simple criteria + reflection

practice_examples.title: Advisory curriculum for belonging and goals
practice_examples.one_liner: A structured advisory supports identity, relationships, and self-direction.
practice_examples.planning: Build a yearly advisory arc (belonging → learning habits → future pathways) with flexible modules; Set up student goal-setting routines (weekly check-in, monthly review); Prepare discussion protocols (circle, prompts) and resources for choice exploration; Coordinate with classroom teachers so goals connect to real academic tasks

What’s my plan?) with peer support; Mini-lessons on learning strategies (time planning, note-taking, stress regulation); Mentor conversations: teacher as coach rather than deliverer of content
practice_examples.assessment: Student-led conference artifacts (goal sheet, evidence samples, reflection); Progress snapshots (self-report + teacher observation) rather than graded tests; Portfolio of learning habits (plans, reflections, strategy logs)

curriculum_design_types.note_on_hybridization: In real settings, design choices are often hybrid; this design type describes the dominant organizing principle.

aims: Support learner agency, identity development, and motivation.
Promote deep understanding through active meaning-making and reflection.
organizing_principle: Learner interest/choice; lived experience; developmental needs.
Flexible pathways; curriculum can be negotiated and responsive.
planning_bias: Broad goals + choice menus rather than fixed content lists.
Co-creating success criteria and routines with learners.
Designing environments (centers/stations/workshop structures) that enable autonomy.
pedagogy_bias: Facilitation, conferencing, coaching, and dialogic teaching.
Project/workshop routines; peer collaboration and feedback.
assessment_bias: Formative assessment, portfolios, reflection, and conferencing evidence.
Growth-oriented criteria; emphasis on process and learner narrative.
evidence_standard: Demonstrated growth, quality of thinking/creation, and reflective awareness.
Learner can articulate goals, strategies, and learning evidence.
typical_tensions: Equity of access to choice vs hidden advantage
common_hybrids: Learner-centered + subject anchors (choice within a disciplined core).
Learner-centered + problem-centered (interest-driven inquiry into real issues).

curriculum_design_types.label: Problem-Centered Design
curriculum_design_types.definition: A curriculum design that organizes learning around real-world problems, issues, or life situations that require integrating knowledge and skills to propose, test, or enact solutions. It emphasizes relevance, inquiry, and the application of learning to authentic contexts.

subtypes.label: Life-Situations (Life-Centered/Core) Design
planning_practices: select life roles/situations (health, finance, citizenship) as organizers
map required knowledge/skills from multiple subjects into themes
instruction_practices: case-based learning; simulations; applied projects
explicit teaching of needed concepts as they arise
assessment_practices: authentic products (budgets, plans, presentations)
scenario-based assessments

practice_examples.title: Life-Situations Unit (Healthy Meal Plan on a Budget)
practice_examples.planning: Create a scenario (weekly budget, dietary needs); map needed skills (unit pricing, nutrition labels); plan mini-lessons and datasets
practice_examples.instruction: Teams design meal plans, justify choices, revise under new constraints; teacher inserts mini-lessons as needed
practice_examples.assessment: Meal plan + cost table; short skill check on calculations; reflection on trade-offs and assumptions
planning_practices: Create a scenario (weekly budget, dietary needs); map needed skills (unit pricing, nutrition labels); plan mini-lessons and datasets

assessment_practices: Meal plan + cost table; short skill check on calculations; reflection on trade-offs and assumptions

subtypes.label: Reconstructionist (Critical/Action) Design
planning_practices: choose public issues with local relevance; map stakeholders and risks
plan inquiry → deliberation → action → reflection cycle
instruction_practices: critical media literacy; community interviews; deliberative forums
student action projects with ethical guidance
assessment_practices: action research report; public product; community partner feedback
rubrics for argument quality, ethics, feasibility, reflection

practice_examples.title: Social Reconstruction Project (School Equity Audit → Action Proposal)
practice_examples.planning: Define an equity-related question; plan data collection ethically; identify stakeholders; plan action proposal criteria (feasibility, justice, impact)
practice_examples.instruction: Student teams gather data (surveys/interviews/documents); analyze patterns; hold deliberation sessions; design interventions and revise
practice_examples.assessment: Public action proposal + evidence dossier; rubric emphasizes critical analysis, evidence use, ethical reasoning, and feasibility

assessment_practices: Public action proposal + evidence dossier; rubric emphasizes critical analysis, evidence use, ethical reasoning, and feasibility

curriculum_design_types.primary_function: Build transferable problem-solving and civic/real-world competence by studying authentic problems.
planning_practices: Select compelling problems/issues; define essential questions and authentic products.
Map required disciplinary knowledge/skills needed to engage the problem.
Plan partnerships, resources, and constraints (time, safety, ethics).
instruction_practices: Project- or problem-based learning cycles; research, debate, design, iteration.
Teacher acts as coach and organizer of inquiry, ensuring rigor and evidence use.
Collaboration and public communication routines are central.
assessment_practices: Performance assessment of products/process (rubrics for inquiry, reasoning, collaboration).
Public exhibitions and reflection on decisions and consequences.
Embedded checks for disciplinary understanding to prevent 'project without learning'.
curriculum_design_types.evidence_standard: Quality of reasoning and action in context: evidence-based solutions, justified decisions, and learned concepts applied appropriately.

practice_examples.title: Community water-quality investigation
practice_examples.one_liner: Students investigate a local water question, analyze data, and communicate findings.
practice_examples.planning: Choose a local issue with reachable data (e.g., water quality, traffic safety, food waste); Write a driving question and map required standards/skills (science + math + language); Secure a stakeholder/partner (city staff, NGO) and plan a fieldwork/data collection day; Create an iteration timeline: investigate → analyze → propose → test/critique → revise
practice_examples.instruction: Teach key tools just-in-time (sampling methods, graphing, claim-evidence reasoning); Student teams collect data, analyze patterns, and build explanations; Critique protocol (gallery walk) to test feasibility and equity impacts; Public communication practice (storytelling with evidence) before final presentation
practice_examples.assessment: Data notebook (methods + raw data + graphs) checked for quality; Written proposal/report + presentation to an authentic audience; Rubric includes: problem framing, evidence quality, feasibility, impact, reflection

practice_examples.title: Media misinformation challenge
practice_examples.one_liner: Students analyze misinformation and design interventions for peers.
practice_examples.planning: Collect a set of real-world claims (ads/posts) and define the problem: 'How do we verify what's true?'; Plan a verification toolkit mini-lesson sequence (lateral reading, source checking, bias detection); Offer product options (fact-check report, PSA video, infographic) with shared success criteria; Prepare a 'claim bank' scaffold so teams can pick a claim at an appropriate difficulty
practice_examples.instruction: Inquiry routine: identify claim → find sources → cross-check → evaluate credibility → conclude; Teacher models lateral reading on one example; teams practice with supports; Structured debate: teams defend their verification process, not just conclusions; Create and revise public-facing messages (PSA) based on peer critique
practice_examples.assessment: Annotated verification dossier (links, notes, reasoning) for one claim; PSA product assessed with rubric (accuracy, evidence trail, clarity, audience impact); Reflection: 'How did my verification process change? What would I do next time?'

practice_examples.title: Life-situations: budgeting and consumer math
practice_examples.one_liner: A practical module organizes math around everyday financial decisions.

curriculum_design_types.note_on_hybridization: In real settings, design choices are often hybrid; this design type describes the dominant organizing principle.

aims: Develop problem-solving, inquiry, and decision-making capacities in authentic contexts.
Cultivate civic/ethical responsibility and the ability to act on issues.
organizing_principle: Driving problems/questions (community, societal, scientific, or personal-life challenges).
Integration across subjects around a shared problem context.
planning_bias: Design a driving question + success criteria for a solution/product.
Backward map needed concepts/skills from the problem demands.
Plan partner/stakeholder interactions and iterative checkpoints.
pedagogy_bias: Inquiry cycles (ask → investigate → analyze → create → critique → revise).
Collaboration, fieldwork, design thinking, and discussion of trade-offs.
assessment_bias: Performance tasks and products (proposals, prototypes, presentations) + reasoning evidence.
Rubrics emphasize problem framing, evidence use, feasibility, and reflection.
evidence_standard: Quality of reasoning and use of evidence in making decisions/solutions.
Ability to transfer learning to new but related problems.
common_hybrids: Problem-centered + subject anchors (mini-lessons to support needed content).

learning_theories.label: Behaviorism
core_claims: learning as change in observable behavior

learning_theories.label: Cognitivism
core_claims: schema, memory limits, and strategy matter

learning_theories.label: Constructivism (incl. social constructivism)
core_claims: learners construct meaning through activity and interaction

curriculum_making_actors.label: International Bodies & Global Benchmarks
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Set comparative frames (discourses, benchmarks, policy narratives) that shape national reforms.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Shape curriculum agendas by circulating transnational discourses (e.g., competencies, accountability, equity), comparative benchmarks, and reform narratives. Their influence is mediated locally through interpretation, negotiation, and selective adoption by national and local actors.
typical_actions: Publish comparative indicators and reports (e.g., international assessments, policy reviews).
Promote frameworks (competencies, standards, accountability) and circulate reform ideas.
Fund or advise reforms; convene networks; influence professional discourse.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Supra influences can be strong but indirect ('soft power'). Local actors may appropriate, resist, or reinterpret these frames.
curriculum_making_actors.priestley_notes: In an enactment perspective, these supra-level frames do not 'determine' curriculum; they enter local webs of curriculum making and are recontextualized through schools, agencies, and practitioners.

curriculum_making_actors.label: Policy Makers
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Authorize curriculum policy, standards, and broad aims; set accountability conditions.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Define official curriculum frameworks and policy expectations, shaping what is considered legitimate knowledge and learning.
typical_actions: Set curriculum standards/outcomes and mandated content (or guiding principles).
Issue policy texts and guidance; define compliance/accountability expectations.
Commission revisions, consultations, and equity/quality initiatives.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Policy signals often become multiple, sometimes contradictory messages once translated through the system.

curriculum_making_actors.label: Assessment Bodies
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Define what counts as evidence of success; shape teaching through assessment regimes.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Set large-scale assessment frameworks that influence curriculum priorities and classroom time.
typical_actions: Design standardized exams/assessments; publish blueprints and performance standards.
Report results and accountability indicators; influence public narratives about quality.
Sometimes provide exemplars, item banks, moderation, and professional learning.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Assessment frameworks can unintentionally narrow enacted curriculum if stakes are high.

curriculum_making_actors.label: System Leaders (District/Authority)
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Translate policy into supports: resources, PD, pacing, and implementation capacity.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Mediate between policy and schools by building structures and supports that shape day-to-day enactment.
typical_actions: Interpret policy; produce local frameworks, pacing guides, and implementation plans.
Allocate resources (staffing, time, PD) and set priorities.
Monitor implementation, collect data, and coordinate interventions.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: System-level support can clarify policy—or increase 'noise' via proliferating guidance and initiatives.

curriculum_making_actors.label: School Leaders
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Shape enacted curriculum via timetables, staffing, culture, and instructional expectations.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Create the institutional conditions (time, culture, priorities) that enable or constrain teachers’ curriculum making.
typical_actions: Set school improvement priorities and curriculum policies (within system constraints).
Organize schedules, staffing, and collaboration time (PLC/teams).
Select/approve materials and programs; broker external support.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Leadership choices influence which curriculum signals get amplified or muted in classrooms.

curriculum_making_actors.label: Publishers / EdTech / Curriculum Brokers
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Package curriculum into materials and tools; strongly shape what is 'doable' in classrooms.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Provide textbooks, programs, platforms, and 'teacher-proof' resources that mediate policy and classroom practice.
typical_actions: Create or adapt materials aligned (sometimes loosely) to standards and assessments.
Offer lesson plans, tasks, and assessments; embed pedagogical routines.
Market solutions and professional learning; influence discourse about 'best practice'.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Materials can stabilize practice but can also narrow professional judgment if treated as scripts.

curriculum_making_actors.label: Teachers
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Interpret and enact curriculum in planning and classroom interaction.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Make situated decisions about content, pedagogy, and assessment; negotiate multiple demands while responding to learners.
typical_actions: Plan units/lessons; select/adapt materials; design classroom assessments.
Teach and orchestrate learning activities; provide feedback and scaffolding.
Interpret policy/standards through professional judgment and local context.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Teacher agency is ecological: it depends on available time, resources, professional norms, and relationships.

curriculum_making_actors.label: Students
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Co-produce the lived curriculum through participation, interpretation, and peer culture.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Shape enacted curriculum in-the-moment through engagement, questions, peer interaction, and meaning-making.
typical_actions: Engage (or not) with tasks; bring prior experiences and identities to learning.
Co-construct meaning through dialogue, collaboration, and peer norms.
Provide feedback signals that influence teacher decisions (pace, scaffolding, focus).
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Students’ agency varies by context, identity, and classroom climate.

curriculum_making_actors.label: Families & Community
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Shape curriculum expectations via values, aspirations, and local knowledge.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Influence curriculum priorities through expectations, cultural norms, and community partnerships.
typical_actions: Communicate aspirations (e.g., 'basics', wellbeing, future readiness).
Support or contest school approaches; participate in school governance or consultations.
Provide local knowledge, resources, and authentic audiences for learning.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Community expectations can align with multiple philosophies; tensions often emerge around assessment, discipline, and relevance.

curriculum_making_actors.label: International Comparative Assessments & Rankings
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Create powerful 'what counts' signals through measurement, comparison, and league tables.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Influence what is valued by defining measurable constructs and producing comparative results. These outputs often travel downstream as accountability pressures, curriculum priorities, and public narratives about quality.
typical_actions: Define frameworks and test constructs (what is measured and how).
Publish rankings/score reports that shape public and political attention.
Provide technical guidance and tools that can steer curriculum emphases.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: The same assessment regime can be mobilized for different philosophical projects (e.g., equity, efficiency, competitiveness). Interpretations vary across contexts.
curriculum_making_actors.priestley_notes: Assessment signals become part of the 'webs of enactment'—they interact with local histories, resources, and professional judgment rather than acting as a simple top-down cause.

curriculum_making_actors.label: Curriculum Brokers / Consultants / Third Sector
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Translate policy and ideas into programs, materials, and implementation packages.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Mediate between policy texts and classroom practice by translating, packaging, and coaching implementation through materials, professional learning, and project-based partnerships.
typical_actions: Develop implementation guides, PD, and toolkits.
Broker partnerships (districts, NGOs, universities, edtech).
Interpret policy and provide 'how-to' models for schools.
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Brokers are not neutral: they may privilege particular conceptions of curriculum and evidence, but they also adapt messages to local contexts.
curriculum_making_actors.priestley_notes: An enactment view highlights the importance of intermediary sites (agencies, consultants, third sector) in curriculum making across multiple locations.

curriculum_making_actors.label: Teacher Education & Universities
curriculum_making_actors.tagline: Shape professional knowledge, discourses, and the 'thinkable' options for practice.
curriculum_making_actors.role_in_curriculum_making: Influence curriculum making by shaping teachers' conceptual repertoires (theories, traditions, inquiry methods), and by participating in research, policy advice, and partnership projects.
typical_actions: Prepare teachers and leaders; circulate research-informed frameworks.
Run partnership projects with schools and systems.
Contribute to public debate and professional standards.
typical_constraints: Disconnect between research and school realities
Access and equity in professional learning
curriculum_making_actors.conceptual_variability_note: Universities host diverse and sometimes competing philosophies and theories; their influence depends on relationships with schools and systems.
curriculum_making_actors.priestley_notes: Curriculum making occurs across multiple sites, including universities; ideas travel and are recontextualized through relationships and local histories.

relationships.non_determinism_rule: No 1:1 mapping is assumed; categories interact under constraints and can be combined.

influence_paths.how: sets what counts as worthwhile outcomes and legitimate knowledge
prioritizes curriculum function which drives organization (scope/sequence/integration) and evidence systems
informs plausible learning pathways and therefore feasible structures (e.g., prerequisite sequencing, practice cycles, inquiry cycles)
shapes task design, scaffolding, feedback, and cognitive/behavioral supports
policy/accountability/resources constrain or enable which hybrids can be sustained

symptoms: teachers disagree on 'what counts as success'
quick_probes: What evidence would convince us learning happened?
Which outcomes are non-negotiable and why?

symptoms: teachers adopt trendy methods but feel ineffective
students engaged but weak on foundational skills (or vice versa)
likely_root_causes: humanistic/constructivist means with essentialist ends without bridge structures
behaviorist drills used for aims requiring inquiry and agency
quick_probes: Do our daily tasks actually practice the outcomes we value?
Where is explicit instruction needed to make inquiry equitable?

symptoms: curriculum vision exists but enactment fails
quick_probes: Which constraints are structural vs negotiable?
Who has authority to change timetable, resources, assessment policy?

primary_views.label: Conceptual View (2D Map)
primary_views.purpose: Explore relationships among philosophy → conception → design, and overlay learning theories.

primary_views.label: Teacher Lens (Disagreement Diagnostic)
primary_views.purpose: Help teachers interpret classroom or PLC disagreements as conceptual misalignments.
core_interactions: see suggested conversation prompts and bridging moves

suggested_additional_views.label: Actor/Power Overlay
suggested_additional_views.idea: Show macro/meso/micro constraints and who controls what (policy, timetable, assessment).

suggested_additional_views.label: Lesson Autopsy
suggested_additional_views.idea: Upload/enter a lesson; tag practices; infer implied conception/design/evidence standard; suggest alignments.

suggested_additional_views.label: Evidence Chain Builder
suggested_additional_views.idea: Start from aims → define success evidence → derive assessment → derive learning tasks.

suggested_additional_views.label: Hybrid Recipe Studio
suggested_additional_views.idea: Choose ends (e.g., essential skills) + choose means (e.g., inquiry) and generate bridging structures (mini-lessons, practice cycles).

suggested_additional_views.label: Case Library
suggested_additional_views.idea: Browse real-ish unit cases; compare how different designs plan/instruct/assess the same topic.

Curriculum making as multi-level, socially situated practice; teacher agency ecological framing.
